questions.text: Identify the X-ray shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

Pulmonary edema is characterized by the bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, which consists of bilateral perihilar opacities with a central distribution. This pattern is due to fluid accumulation in the lung interstitium and alveoli, commonly seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

 

Typical X-ray findings of pulmonary edema include:

 

  • Bilateral perihilar opacities (bat-wing distribution)
  • Kerley B lines (horizontal lines indicating interstitial edema)
  • Cardiomegaly (if due to heart failure)
  • Pleural effusions in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural Effusion: Characterized by blunting of the costophrenic angles and a meniscus sign due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Shows reticular opacities in the lower lung zones, often with honeycombing and volume loss. It does not have a central perihilar distribution.

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Similar to pleural effusion, hydrothorax refers to fluid accumulation in the pleural space, seen as homogeneous opacity with a fluid level

​

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary edema presents with a bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, characterized by bilateral perihilar opacities, Kerley B lines, and signs of interstitial fluid accumulation.

choices.text: 50 breaths per minute or more

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above 

 

Explanation: 

 

The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.

 

The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.

 

Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.

 

Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with epiphora. Probing revealed a soft block at 7 mm. This can be treated by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conjunctival DCR

 

Explanation: 

 

Epiphora refers to the overflow of tears onto the face due to inadequate drainage. In this case, probing revealed a blockage at the 7 mm mark of the lacrimal drainage system. 

 

The lacrimal drainage system begins at the punctum and continues through the canaliculus, which has a 2 mm vertical segment followed by an 8 mm horizontal segment. The canaliculi then join to form a common canaliculus before entering the lacrimal sac. The total distance from the punctum to the lacrimal sac is approximately 10 mm.

 

Since the block is at 7 mm, it is located within the horizontal portion of the canaliculus, before reaching the lacrimal sac. When the obstruction is in the canaliculus itself, neither external DCR nor endoscopic DCR would be effective because these procedures address nasolacrimal duct obstruction, not canalicular obstruction.

 

Conjunctival DCR (also known as conjunctivodacryocystorhinostomy or CDCR) is the appropriate procedure, as it bypasses the obstructed canalicular system entirely by creating a new passage directly from the conjunctival sac to the nasal cavity. This is typically done using a Jones tube, which is a glass or silicone tube that connects the medial canthus to the middle meatus of the nose.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extranasal DCR: Incorrect. External dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a procedure that creates a new pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing the bone between them. It is indicated when the obstruction is in the nasolacrimal duct, not in the canaliculus. Since the block in this case is at 7 mm (within the canaliculus), an external DCR would not address the site of obstruction.

 

Option B. Endoscopic DCR: Incorrect. Endoscopic DCR, like external DCR, creates a passage between the lacrimal sac and nasal cavity, but it is performed using an endoscope through the nasal cavity without an external incision. It is also used for nasolacrimal duct obstructions, not canalicular obstructions. Since the block in this case is in the canaliculus, endoscopic DCR would not be effective.

 

Option D. Dacryocystectomy: Incorrect. Dacryocystectomy involves the surgical removal of the lacrimal sac. It is typically performed in cases of chronic dacryocystitis with an atonic (non-functioning) lacrimal sac or in certain lacrimal sac tumors. This procedure completely eliminates the tear drainage system without providing an alternative drainage pathway, resulting in permanent epiphora. It is not appropriate for a canalicular obstruction in a young child were preserving or creating a functional drainage system is the goal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Canalicular obstructions (as evidenced by a block at 7 mm from the punctum) are treated with conjunctival DCR (CDCR) using a Jones tube, which bypasses the obstructed lacrimal drainage system by creating a direct connection between the conjunctival sac and the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Who conducts inquest in police custodial death? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Judicial magistrate

 

In India, an inquest can be conducted by either the police or a magistrate. A police inquest is the most common type of inquest. However, a magistrate inquest is conducted in specific cases. There are two types of magistrates who can conduct inquests: an executive magistrate and a judicial magistrate.

 

  • Executive Magistrate Inquest: This is performed in cases of dowry deaths and exhumation.
  • Judicial Magistrate Inquest: This is conducted in cases of custodial deaths, which can occur in various forms of custody such as police custody, prison, psychiatric hospitals, or rehabilitation homes where an under-trial accused might be placed.

 

Therefore, in the event of a police custodial death, the inquest is conducted by a judicial magistrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Higher police official: While higher police officials may be involved in various administrative and investigative roles, they do not conduct inquests in cases of custodial deaths. The judicial magistrate is the designated authority for this purpose to ensure an unbiased investigation.

 

Option C. Medical examiner: A medical examiner conducts autopsies and determines the cause of death, but does not conduct inquests. The role of the medical examiner is critical in providing medical evidence that supports the inquest.

 

Option D. Coroner: The office of the coroner is not part of the Indian legal system. Instead, the role typically carried out by a coroner in other jurisdictions is fulfilled by magistrates in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the inquest for a police custodial death is conducted by a judicial magistrate, ensuring an impartial investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death.

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetaminophen

 

In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like naproxen, indomethacin, and diclofenac are generally avoided due to their potential to worsen renal function. These medications inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which can lead to renal vasoconstriction and further decline in kidney function.

 

Acetaminophen (paracetamol), on the other hand, is generally considered safer for patients with CKD when used at appropriate doses. It has a different mechanism of action (inhibit COX3) and does not significantly affect renal hemodynamics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naproxen: Naproxen is an NSAID that can significantly impair renal function, especially in patients with pre-existing kidney disease. It should be avoided in this population due to the risk of worsening kidney function and potential for causing renal failure.

 

Option B. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is another NSAID with similar risks to naproxen. Its use can lead to decreased renal perfusion and exacerbate renal impairment, making it unsuitable for patients with CKD.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac, like other NSAIDs, poses a significant risk to kidney function in patients with CKD. It can reduce prostaglandin synthesis, leading to renal vasoconstriction and further renal impairment, and should be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetaminophen is the preferred postoperative analgesic for patients with chronic kidney disease, as it does not significantly affect renal function and is safer than NSAIDs in this population.

questions.text: In a normal distribution for weights of a class of college students, Mean value is 82 kg. The calculated SD is 1.5 kg. Calculate the range of weight for 95% students covering 2 SD. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 79 – 85 kg

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 2SD covers 95% of all values
  • Formula: Range = Mean ± (2 × SD)
  • Given: Mean = 82 kg, SD = 1.5 kg
  • Therefore: Range = 82 ± (2 × 1.5) = 82 ± 3 = 79 to 85 kg This means 95% of students will have weights between 79 and 85 kg.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 1SD includes 68% of values
  • Mean ± 2SD includes 95% of values
  • Mean ± 3SD includes 99.7% of values

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports episodes of palpitations and dizziness, particularly following physical activity such as playing tennis. She has experienced these symptoms multiple times over the last two years. ECG is taken and it is shown. Based on her presentation and the accompanying ECG findings, which of the following diagnoses is most likely? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

 

The diagnosis of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is based on:

 

  1. A young patient with exertional palpitations and dizziness
  2. ECG shows characteristic epsilon waves—multiple wavelet-like appearances at the J point
  3. T-wave inversions in V1–V4 indicating RV strain/dysfunction
  4. This condition involves fibro-fatty replacement of right ventricular myocardium in the "triangle of dysplasia"

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: Incorrect. It typically causes arrhythmias during rest, not exertion. ECG shows characteristic ST elevation with "coved" appearance in V1–V3, not epsilon waves.

 

Option B. Uhl anomaly: Incorrect. It involves congenital absence of right ventricular musculature, which doesn't match the ECG findings or clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy: Incorrect. ECG would show LVH with Sokolov-Lyon criteria (S in V1 + R in V5/V6 > 35mm) and septal Q waves in lateral leads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon waves on ECG are pathognomonic for ARVD, which typically presents in young people with exertional symptoms and can be a cause of sudden cardiac death, particularly common in Italy. The condition involves desmosomal mutations and progressive RV dysfunction.

questions.text: For HbA1c sample, the vacutainer used contains which of the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is measured to assess long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. The preferred sample for HbA1c estimation is whole blood, and the anticoagulant used for this is EDTA.

 

  • EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used because:
    • It prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    • It preserves RBC integrity, ensuring accurate measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin.
    • Lavender-top (Purple) vacutainers contain EDTA and are commonly used for HbA1c testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: 

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant used therapeutically, not for blood collection.

 

Option B. Sodium Fluoride:

 

  • Used in gray-top vacutainers, primarily for glucose estimation, as it inhibits glycolysis.
  • Does not preserve RBCs well, so not used for HbA1c.

 

Option D. Heparin:

 

  • Used in green-top vacutainers, primarily for plasma-based tests (e.g., electrolytes, arterial blood gases).
  • Not used for HbA1c, as it does not preserve whole blood effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HbA1c estimation, EDTA (lavender-top vacutainer) is used because it prevents coagulation while preserving RBC integrity for accurate glycosylated hemoglobin measurement.

 

Vacutainer Vials and Their Uses

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

questions.text: Match the following Amino acid products: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

 

  • Tyrosine (A) → Norepinephrine (3): Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. It's also used for melanin and thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Tryptophan (B) → melatonin (1): Tryptophan is metabolized to serotonin, which is then converted to melatonin. Tryptophan is also a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3).
  • Glycine (C) → Glutathione (2): Glycine is one of the three amino acids that make up glutathione (along with glutamate and cysteine). Glycine is also used in heme synthesis, creatine synthesis, and bile acid conjugation.
  • Histidine (D) → Histamine (4): Histidine undergoes decarboxylation (removal of the carboxyl group) to form histamine, which is an important inflammatory mediator and neurotransmitter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino Acid Conversions

questions.text: Which structure constitutes the base of the heart? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The base of the heart is formed mainly by the left atrium with a small contribution from the right atrium. The base is also called the posterior surface of the heart. It faces posteriorly toward the vertebral column and forms the posterior boundary of the heart. This base is separated from the vertebral column by the pericardium, the right pulmonary veins, the esophagus, and the aorta. The posterior surface receives the four pulmonary veins (two right and two left) which open into the left atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left ventricle: The left ventricle forms the apex of the heart, not the base. It constitutes most of the left border, part of the sternocostal surface, and the inferolateral surface of the heart.

 

Option B. Right ventricle: The right ventricle forms the inferior border and most of the sternocostal surface of the heart. It does not contribute to the base of the heart.

 

Option C. Right atrium: While the right atrium does contribute to the base of the heart, it forms only a small part (approximately one-third), with the left atrium forming the major component (approximately two-thirds) of the base.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The base or posterior surface of the heart is predominantly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) with a smaller contribution from the right atrium (one-third).

choices.text: Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus
Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation
Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death

questions.text: All of the following statements about the Prinsloo-Gordon artefact are true, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation

 

Explanation:

 

The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact is not a definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation. It is actually a postmortem artifact that can be mistaken for an antemortem injury. This hemorrhagic appearance on the posterior wall of the esophagus is caused by postmortem blood leakage from esophageal venous plexuses and can be confused with signs of trauma if misinterpreted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Described by Prinsloo and Gordon - This statement is CORRECT. The artifact was indeed described by and named after Prinsloo and Gordon, who identified this postmortem phenomenon.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus - This statement is CORRECT. The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact appears as hemorrhage or hemorrhagic-like discoloration on the posterior surface of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death - This statement is CORRECT. The artifact is caused by postmortem leakage of blood from the esophageal venous plexuses, which creates hemorrhagic-appearing areas that can be confused with traumatic injuries.

 

Key Points About Prinsloo-Gordon Artifact

  • Appears as hemorrhagic discoloration on the posterior wall of the esophagus
  • Postmortem phenomenon, not an antemortem injury
  • Can be mistaken for evidence of trauma, particularly neck trauma
  • Important for forensic pathologists to recognize to avoid misinterpretation
  • Does not indicate any specific cause of death

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact is a postmortem change that may mimic traumatic injury but is not a definitive sign of manual strangulation, highlighting the importance of distinguishing between genuine antemortem injuries and postmortem artifacts in forensic pathology.

questions.text: From which germ layer are astrocytes derived? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroectoderm

 

Explanation:

 

Astrocytes are derived from neuroectoderm. Neuroectoderm is a specialized portion of ectoderm that forms the neural tube and neural crest. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, including neurons and neuroglial cells. Astrocytes are a type of neuroglial cell that form within the central nervous system. They develop from glioblasts (also called spongioblasts), which in turn derive from the germinal neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube wall after they cease to produce neuroblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because mesoderm gives rise to structures like bone, cartilage, muscle, blood, connective tissue, and the urogenital system. While mesoderm contributes to the vascular elements in the nervous system and forms microglia (which are mesodermal in origin), it does not form astrocytes.

 

Option c) Endoderm - This is incorrect because endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, bladder, and associated glands. Endoderm has no role in forming any components of the central nervous system, including astrocytes.

 

Option d) None - This is incorrect because astrocytes definitely have a germ layer of origin, which is neuroectoderm.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Astrocytes are neuroglial cells that develop from glioblasts derived from the neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube, making them neuroectodermal in origin. This is consistent with most of the cellular elements of the central nervous system which derive from neuroectoderm

questions.text:
Which of these are included in extra-esophageal symptoms of GERD? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Asthma
b. Laryngitis
c. Excessive phlegm
d. Pulmonary fibrosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is typically associated with symptoms such as heartburn, epigastric pain, and acid reflux. However, GERD can also present with a variety of extra-esophageal symptoms, which are manifestations outside the esophagus. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents or the stimulation of vagal reflexes.

 

  • Asthma: Nocturnal asthma can be triggered or exacerbated by GERD due to the reflux of stomach acid that can reach the airways, leading to bronchoconstriction.
  • Laryngitis: Laryngitis can occur when acid reflux irritates the laryngeal mucosa, leading to hoarseness or loss of voice.
  • Excessive phlegm: GERD can lead to chronic throat clearing and excessive phlegm production as the body attempts to clear the irritating reflux material from the throat.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Although less common, repeated aspiration of gastric contents can cause chronic inflammation in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Since the  includes all options, there are no incorrect choices to explain in this instance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can manifest not only with typical esophageal symptoms like heartburn but also with extra-esophageal symptoms such as asthma, laryngitis, excessive phlegm, and even pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Which type of vertebrae feature a long spinous process? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Thoracic vertebrae

 

Explanation:

 

Thoracic vertebrae have long, slender, downward-directed spinous processes that are especially prominent in the mid-thoracic region. This characteristic feature is related to their functional role in providing attachment sites for the muscles of the back and for supporting the rib cage. The overlapping nature of these processes helps limit excessive extension of the thoracic spine, contributing to the stability of this region.

 

Other Options:

 

A) Cervical vertebrae - These have short, bifid (split) spinous processes rather than long ones. The bifid nature allows for attachment of multiple muscles while maintaining the neck's flexibility.

 

C) Lumbar vertebrae - Lumbar vertebrae have short, thick, horizontally-directed (rather than downward) spinous processes that are quadrangular in shape, designed to withstand greater stress in the lower back.

 

D) Sacrum - The sacrum is a fused bone consisting of five vertebrae, with rudimentary spinous processes that appear as the median sacral crest rather than distinct long processes.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Thoracic vertebrae are characterized by long, downward-sloping spinous processes that provide stability to the thoracic region and attachment points for back muscles while contributing to the limited mobility of this portion of the spine.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: What is the postnatal remnant of the distal umbilical artery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Medial umbilical ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The distal part of the umbilical artery transforms into the medial umbilical ligament postnatally. This occurs as part of the normal circulatory changes following birth when the placental circulation is no longer needed. The proximal portions of the umbilical arteries remain patent and form the superior vesical arteries, while the distal portions become fibrous cords that appear as medial umbilical folds on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum teres: This is incorrect. The ligamentum teres is the postnatal remnant of the umbilical vein, not the umbilical artery. It extends from the umbilicus to the porta hepatis and represents the obliterated umbilical vein.

 

Option B. Superior vesical artery: This is incorrect. The superior vesical artery is derived from the proximal portion of the umbilical artery that remains patent after birth, not the distal portion which becomes ligamentous.

 

Option D. Ligamentum arteriosum: This is incorrect. The ligamentum arteriosum is the postnatal remnant of the ductus arteriosus (which connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta in fetal life), not the umbilical artery.

 

Education Objective:

 

The distal parts of paired umbilical arteries, after cessation of placental circulation at birth, become fibrous cords known as medial umbilical ligaments, while their proximal portions remain patent as the superior vesical arteries.

questions.text: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 10 mg/L.

 

Fluoride is an element that, in appropriate concentrations, can prevent dental caries, but excessive intake can lead to various forms of fluorosis. The concentration of fluoride in drinking water (0.5-0.8 ppm or mg/L) is a key determinant of its effects on health.

 

  • Dental fluorosis typically occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 1.5 mg/L.
  • Skeletal fluorosis may develop when the concentration of fluoride in drinking water is between 3 to 6 mg/L.
  • Crippling fluorosis, the most severe form of fluorosis, occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 10 mg/L. At this level, the fluoride can cause severe joint pain, bone deformities, and can result in significant disability.

 

Thus, a fluoride concentration of greater than 10 mg/L is associated with the development of crippling fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Fluorine is a double edged sword’: Inadequate intake is associated with ‘dental caries’ whereas excess intake with ‘dental and skeletal fluorosis’

 

Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 10 mg/L, leading to severe and disabling conditions.

choices.text: Lyophylised Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voriconazole

 

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

 

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: While effective against Aspergillus species, itraconazole is generally considered less effective than voriconazole for invasive cases due to its variable bioavailability and slower onset of action.

 

Option C. Lyophylised Amphotericin B: Often used as a second-line treatment or in patients who cannot tolerate azole antifungals. It has a broader spectrum but is also associated with more severe side effects, particularly nephrotoxicity.

 

Option D. Posaconazole: This is another alternative, especially for prophylaxis against Aspergillus in high-risk patients, but it is generally used when voriconazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voriconazole's effectiveness, broad spectrum of activity, and favorable pharmacokinetic profile make it the first-line treatment for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, offering significant benefits in terms of efficacy and patient outcomes in severe fungal infections.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with fever and fatigue 3 weeks after undergoing mitral valve replacement surgery. Blood cultures are positive for a gram-positive cocci that produces a biofilm. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of his condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus epidermidis

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most likely causative organism in this case. It is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus that commonly causes infections associated with prosthetic devices, including prosthetic heart valves. S. epidermidis is known for its ability to produce biofilms, which are extracellular polymeric substances that allow the bacteria to adhere to foreign materials like prosthetic valves. The biofilm also protects the bacteria from antibiotics and host immune responses, making these infections difficult to treat. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: Incorrect. S. pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is not typically associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis. It more commonly causes pharyngitis, impetigo, necrotizing fasciitis, and rheumatic fever. It does not characteristically form biofilms on prosthetic materials.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Incorrect. While S. pneumoniae can cause native valve endocarditis, it is not commonly associated with prosthetic valve infections or biofilm formation. It is primarily a respiratory pathogen causing pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis media, and meningitis.

 

Option D. Escherichia coli: Incorrect. E. coli is a gram-negative rod, not a gram-positive cocci. While it can cause various infections including urinary tract infections and sepsis, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus that commonly causes prosthetic valve endocarditis due to its ability to form biofilms on foreign materials, typically presenting weeks after valve replacement surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

 

The patient's presentation and findings are indicative of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump effectively. This condition can result from various causes, including pericarditis, malignancy, trauma, or post-myocardial infarction.

 

Key features supporting cardiac tamponade:

 

  1. Chest pain and dyspnea: These symptoms can worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, a condition known as orthopnea.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Due to the fluid in the pericardial sac, the heart sounds are dampened.
  3. Clear lungs: This helps differentiate from pulmonary causes of dyspnea.
  4. Enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR: The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, indicative of pericardial effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Pulmonary edema: This condition typically presents with bilateral crackles on lung auscultation and possibly a history of heart failure. The chest X-ray would show features like Kerley B lines, pleural effusions, or alveolar edema, which are absent in this case.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary embolism: This can present with dyspnea and chest pain, but the ECG findings and clear lung fields on auscultation are less supportive. Additionally, acute pulmonary embolism typically does not cause an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

 

Option C. Acute MI (Myocardial Infarction): While acute MI can present with chest pain and dyspnea, it usually does not result in muffled heart sounds or an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Acute MI would more likely present with changes on ECG and possibly signs of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

In cases where a patient has dyslipidemia with persistently elevated triglyceride levels, particularly above 500 mg/dL, there is a significant risk of developing pancreatitis. The primary goal in such situations is to lower the triglyceride levels to mitigate this risk. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil or fenofibrate, are the treatment of choice for reducing triglyceride levels effectively. They act by decreasing the hepatic secretion of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and increasing the clearance of triglycerides from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is used to reduce low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels. It works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. While it is effective for lowering LDL, it is not the first-line treatment for elevated triglycerides.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, or vitamin B3, was previously used to lower both LDL and triglyceride levels. However, it is no longer commonly used in practice due to its side effects and lack of significant additional benefit over other treatments.

 

Option D. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol. It is not particularly effective in reducing triglyceride levels and can cause gastrointestinal side effects, making it a less favorable option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, fibrates such as gemfibrozil are the preferred treatment to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

choices.text: Weight for height <3 SD of WHO Standard
Height for Age <2 SD of WHO Standard

questions.text: Severe Acute Malnutrition is defined by all of the following criteria, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Height for Age <2 SD of WHO Standard 

 

Explanation: 

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is defined by specific anthropometric and clinical criteria. According to the WHO classification, SAM includes weight for height <-3 SD (severe wasting), mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm (<115 mm) in children 6-59 months, and bilateral pitting edema (kwashiorkor) regardless of anthropometric measurements. Height for age <-2 SD defines stunting, which is a marker of chronic malnutrition rather than acute malnutrition, making it not a criterion for SAM diagnosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mid-Upper-Arm Circumference <115mm - This is a correct criterion for SAM diagnosis. MUAC <11.5 cm indicates severe acute malnutrition in children aged 6-59 months and is a simple field measurement tool.

 

Option B. Weight for height <3 SD of WHO Standard - This is a correct criterion for SAM, indicating severe wasting. It reflects acute weight loss or failure to gain weight relative to height.

 

Option D. Bilateral Pitting Edema - This is a correct criterion for SAM diagnosis regardless of anthropometric measurements. It indicates kwashiorkor, a form of SAM characterized by protein deficiency leading to fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed by weight for height <-3 SD, MUAC <11.5 cm, or bilateral pitting edema, while stunting (height for age <-2 SD) reflects chronic malnutrition and is not part of SAM diagnostic criteria.
